text: Who is the primary author of the Epistle to the Philippians?
verseText: Paul and Timothy, servants of Christ Jesus, To all the saints in Christ Jesus who are at Philippi, with the overseers and deacons:

text: From where did Paul likely write Philippians?
verseText: so that it has become known throughout the whole imperial guard and to all the rest that my imprisonment is for Christ. And most of the brothers, having become confident in the Lord by my imprisonment, are much more bold to speak the word without fear.

text: What is a dominant theme throughout Philippians, despite Paul's imprisonment?
verseText: always in every prayer of mine for you all making my prayer with joy... Yes, and I will rejoice... Even if I am to be poured out as a drink offering upon the sacrificial offering of your faith, I am glad and rejoice with you all. Likewise you also should be glad and rejoice with me... Finally, my brothers, rejoice in the Lord... Rejoice in the Lord always; again I will say, rejoice.

text: Philippians 1:21 contains Paul's famous statement: 'For to me to live is Christ, and to die is...' what?
verseText: For to me to live is Christ, and to die is gain.

text: What passage in Philippians 2 describes Christ's humility, incarnation, and exaltation (often called the 'Kenosis Hymn')?
verseText: Have this mind among yourselves, which is yours in Christ Jesus, who, though he was in the form of God, did not count equality with God a thing to be grasped, but emptied himself, by taking the form of a servant, being born in the likeness of men... Therefore God has highly exalted him...

text: In Philippians 3, Paul contrasts confidence in the flesh (his former Jewish credentials) with what?
options: The surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus
verseText: But whatever gain I had, I counted as loss for the sake of Christ. Indeed, I count everything as loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have suffered the loss of all things and count them as rubbish, in order that I may gain Christ

text: What does Paul urge the Philippians to do in Philippians 4:6 instead of being anxious?
verseText: do not be anxious about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God.

text: What is the result promised in Philippians 4:7 for those who pray with thanksgiving?
options: The peace of God, which surpasses all understanding
verseText: And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.

text: What does Paul say he has learned in Philippians 4:11-13?
options: The secret of contentment in any circumstance through Christ
verseText: Not that I am speaking of being in need, for I have learned in whatever situation I am to be content. I know how to be brought low, and I know how to abound. In any and every circumstance, I have learned the secret of facing plenty and hunger, abundance and need. I can do all things through him who strengthens me.

text: Paul thanks the Philippians for their partnership in the gospel, particularly for what practical support?
options: Sending him financial gifts and support
verseText: I rejoiced in the Lord greatly that now at length you have revived your concern for me... And you Philippians yourselves know that in the beginning of the gospel, when I left Macedonia, no church entered into partnership with me in giving and receiving, except you only. Even in Thessalonica you sent me help for my needs once and again.

text: Besides Paul, who is mentioned as a servant of Christ Jesus in the opening greeting of Philippians?
verseText: Paul and Timothy, servants of Christ Jesus, To all the saints in Christ Jesus who are at Philippi, with the overseers and deacons:

text: Paul expresses his longing for the Philippians with the affection of whom?
verseText: For God is my witness, how I yearn for you all with the affection of Christ Jesus.

text: What does Paul pray will abound more and more for the Philippians, along with knowledge and discernment?
verseText: And it is my prayer that your love may abound more and more, with knowledge and all discernment,

text: Paul saw his imprisonment not as a setback, but as an opportunity for what?
verseText: I want you to know, brothers, that what has happened to me has really served to advance the gospel, so that it has become known throughout the whole imperial guard and to all the rest that my imprisonment is for Christ.

text: How did Paul feel about others preaching Christ, even if from envy or rivalry?
verseText: What then? Only that in every way, whether in pretense or in truth, Christ is proclaimed, and in that I rejoice. Yes, and I will rejoice.

text: Paul urges the Philippians to live their lives in a manner worthy of what?
verseText: Only let your manner of life be worthy of the gospel of Christ, so that whether I come and see you or am absent, I may hear of you that you are standing firm in one spirit, with one mind striving side by side for the faith of the gospel,

text: What characteristic does Paul emphasize should mark the Philippians' interactions, urging them to be of the same mind and love?
verseText: complete my joy by being of the same mind, having the same love, being in full accord and of one mind. Do nothing from selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility count others more significant than yourselves.

text: The famous passage describing Christ 'emptying himself' highlights which divine attribute being set aside in incarnation?
verseText: who, though he was in the form of God, did not count equality with God a thing to be grasped, but emptied himself, by taking the form of a servant, being born in the likeness of men.

text: According to the Christ hymn in Philippians, what is the ultimate outcome of Christ's obedience unto death?
verseText: And being found in human form, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to the point of death, even death on a cross. Therefore God has highly exalted him and bestowed on him the name that is above every name,

text: What action does Paul instruct the Philippians to 'work out' with fear and trembling?
verseText: Therefore, my beloved, as you have always obeyed, so now, not only as in my presence but much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling,

text: Who does Paul say is working in the believers both to will and to work for His good pleasure?
verseText: for it is God who works in you, both to will and to work for his good pleasure.

text: Paul encourages the Philippians to live without grumbling or disputing so they may shine as what in the world?
verseText: Do all things without grumbling or disputing, that you may be blameless and innocent, children of God without blemish in the midst of a crooked and twisted generation, among whom you shine as lights in the world,

text: Who did Paul hope to send to the Philippians soon, describing him as having a genuine concern for their welfare?
verseText: I hope in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you soon, so that I too may be cheered by news of you. For I have no one like him, who will be genuinely concerned for your welfare.

text: Who does Paul describe as his brother, fellow worker, fellow soldier, and messenger from the Philippians?
verseText: I have thought it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus my brother and fellow worker and fellow soldier, and your messenger and minister to my need,

text: Why was Epaphroditus distressed while away from the Philippians?
options: Because the Philippians heard he had been sick
verseText: for he has been longing for you all and has been distressed because you heard that he was ill.

text: Paul warns the Philippians to look out for whom, referring to them as 'dogs' and 'evildoers'?
verseText: Look out for the dogs, look out for the evildoers, look out for those who mutilate the flesh.

text: What does Paul consider 'rubbish' or 'loss' compared to the surpassing worth of knowing Christ?
options: His former status and achievements under the Law
verseText: But whatever gain I had, I counted as loss for the sake of Christ. Indeed, I count everything as loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have suffered the loss of all things and count them as rubbish, in order that I may gain Christ

text: Paul states his desire is to know Christ and the power of His resurrection, and also share in what?
verseText: that I may know him and the power of his resurrection, and may share his sufferings, becoming like him in his death,

text: What athletic metaphor does Paul use to describe his pursuit of the heavenly call in Christ Jesus?
options: Running a race (pressing toward the goal)
verseText: But one thing I do: forgetting what lies behind and straining forward to what lies ahead, I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus.

text: Paul contrasts those whose 'god is their belly' and mind is set on earthly things with believers, whose citizenship is where?
verseText: Their end is destruction, their god is their belly, and they glory in their shame, with minds set on earthly things. But our citizenship is in heaven, and from it we await a Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ,

text: From heaven, who do believers eagerly await, according to Paul?
options: A Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ
verseText: But our citizenship is in heaven, and from it we await a Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ,

text: What will Christ do to our lowly bodies when He returns, according to Philippians?
options: Transform them to be like His glorious body
verseText: who will transform our lowly body to be like his glorious body, by the power that enables him even to subject all things to himself.

text: Which two women does Paul specifically plead with to 'agree in the Lord'?
verseText: I entreat Euodia and I entreat Syntyche to agree in the Lord.

text: Who does Paul ask his 'true companion' to help, mentioning they labored side by side with him in the gospel?
verseText: Yes, I ask you also, true companion, help these women, who have labored side by side with me in the gospel together with Clement and the rest of my fellow workers, whose names are in the book of life.

text: What quality does Paul command the Philippians to let be known to everyone, adding 'The Lord is at hand'?
verseText: Let your reasonableness be known to everyone. The Lord is at hand;

text: Paul instructs believers to think about things that possess which qualities?
options: True, honorable, just, pure, lovely, commendable
verseText: Finally, brothers, whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is just, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is commendable, if there is any excellence, if there is anything worthy of praise, think about these things.

text: What does Paul say will be the result of practicing the things learned, received, heard, and seen in him?
options: The God of peace will be with them
verseText: What you have learned and received and heard and seen in me—practice these things, and the God of peace will be with you.

text: Paul rejoiced that the Philippians had revived their concern for him, comparing it to what?
verseText: I rejoiced in the Lord greatly that now at length you have revived your concern for me. You were indeed concerned for me, but you had no opportunity. (Implied metaphor of revival/blooming)

text: Through whom does Paul declare he can do all things?
verseText: I can do all things through him who strengthens me.

text: Paul commends the Philippians for being the only church to enter into partnership with him in what specific way when he left Macedonia?
verseText: And you Philippians yourselves know that in the beginning of the gospel, when I left Macedonia, no church entered into partnership with me in giving and receiving, except you only.

text: What does Paul desire more than the gift itself from the Philippians?
options: The fruit that increases to their credit
verseText: Not that I seek the gift, but I seek the fruit that increases to your credit.

text: How does Paul describe the gift received from the Philippians via Epaphroditus?
options: A fragrant offering, an acceptable sacrifice
verseText: I have received full payment, and more. I am well supplied, having received from Epaphroditus the gifts you sent, a fragrant offering, a sacrifice acceptable and pleasing to God.

text: According to Paul's promise, how will God supply every need of the Philippians?
options: According to His riches in glory in Christ Jesus
Through the generosity of other churches
verseText: And my God will supply every need of yours according to his riches in glory in Christ Jesus.

text: From where does Paul send greetings, specifically mentioning 'those of Caesar's household'?
verseText: All the saints greet you, especially those of Caesar's household.
